instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3662: What is 820-3662? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PP5V_S4: What is PP5V_S4? PP5V_S4 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..
definitions.PP5VS4_EN: What is PP5VS4_EN? P5VS4_EN is a signal that enables the power chip responsible for creating PP5V_S4 when it is high. Signals with _EN mean that whatever is mentioned before the _EN will be enabled or turned on when the signal is high. .
definitions.U1950: What is U1950? This chip often becomes corroded on pin 8 on the PP3V42_G3H pin causing PM_SLP_S4_L to go missing.
definitions.U6100: What is U6100? this is an SPI ROM chip that holds the BIOS which is necessary for the machine to POST or try and power on..
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.PM_S0_PGOOD: What is PM_S0_PGOOD?  PM_S0_PGOOD is created when CPUVR_PGOOD and ALL_SYS_PWRGD are present and branches off to become PM_PCH_PWROK. PM_S0_PGOOD and SMC_DELAYED_PWRGD are necessary to create SYS_PWROK_R and PM_PCH_SYS_PWROK .
definitions.ALL_SYS: What is ALL_SYS? This is a typo of ALL_SYS_PWRGD When you see ALL_SYS, assume they meant to type ALL_SYS_PWRGD.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Fans spin for a few seconds over and over.
threads.message:
As in the title the fans spin for a few seconds then stop. Then spin a few seconds then stop and so for ever.

Laptop looks absolutely spotless. Customer said it has been in a cupboard for a couple months.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Fans spin for a few seconds over and over.
threads.message: CPU Vcore on L7310 coming on?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Fans spin for a few seconds over and over.
threads.message:
Trying to find documentation for this board.

Will get back to you shortly.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Fans spin for a few seconds over and over.
threads.message:
Sorry, I thought I had the info for this board. Had it confused with the 3332 for a second.

L7310 is very unstable. It goes from 1.7v down to 0 and back up.

<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> @ <CAPACITOR>C7310</CAPACITOR> keeps dropping out.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Fans spin for a few seconds over and over.
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> is stable at 5.04v
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL> drops to 0v every four or five seconds.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Fans spin for a few seconds over and over.
threads.message:
<CHIP>U8170</CHIP>::4 drops to 0 every few seconds.

This controls <SIGNAL>PP5VS4_EN</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Fans spin for a few seconds over and over.
threads.message: Power cycling.....Could be absolutely anything if there is no water damage. Inspect for corrosion or damaged/missing parts. This kind of behavior usually does not "just" happen.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Fans spin for a few seconds over and over.
threads.message:
So the problem is not with <CHIP>U8170</CHIP>?

The board is spotless, no corrosion what-so-ever.

Just to be clear, only the 5v rails are power cycling and only from <SIGNAL>PP5VS4_EN</SIGNAL>.

<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> is stable.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Fans spin for a few seconds over and over.
threads.message: Why would <CHIP>U8170</CHIP> be responsible, it is just <SIGNAL>SLP_S5</SIGNAL> cycling? The whole board is power cycling and this could be anything. Unless you can find a clue this thing will be a nightmare.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Fans spin for a few seconds over and over.
threads.message:
Hang on, I think I'm missing something here.

The whole board isn't power cycling. <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> (and the 3v lines) is rock solid stable, only <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL> and onwards are cycling.
The power going into <CHIP>U8170</CHIP> is stable, but the <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4_EN</SIGNAL> coming out is going up and down.

If the board keeps loosing the <SIGNAL>5V_S4_EN</SIGNAL> signal, wouldn't this cause the 5v power rails above S4 to keep dropping out?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Fans spin for a few seconds over and over.
threads.message: Yes that is called power cycling. S5 is of course fine. My verdict still stands, this board is a rabbit hole without any clues to what happened. Could be corrupt BIOS if you want to try that, backup the original!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Fans spin for a few seconds over and over.
threads.message:
OK thanks.
Been a steep learning curve on this board...

Do you happen to have a bios binary for the 3662 with a clean ME region handy?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Fans spin for a few seconds over and over.
threads.message:
Here is a locked 3662, good enough for testing I guess. If it works we can fix your original BIOS.
[url]https://drive.google.com/open?id=0ByfhQ_x0v-tZLWZfM3VZT3Q1WWs[/url]

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Fans spin for a few seconds over and over.
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Fans spin for a few seconds over and over.
threads.message:
This board came back to me finally.

Flashed the bios, exactly the same behaviour.

Sometimes only one fan spins. :/

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Fans spin for a few seconds over and over.
threads.message: When I connect power I can hear something softly go Click-Click, then a second later the one fan starts spinning. Maybe something is tripping?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Fans spin for a few seconds over and over.
threads.message: I have no idea. If Vcore is pulsing too then it could be about anything. Check termination resistors to <CHIP>U6100</CHIP> and see if power good signal comes from <CHIP>U1950</CHIP>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Fans spin for a few seconds over and over.
threads.message:
Yes, VCore drops to 0, then tries again.

With <CHIP>U1950</CHIP>, I can't get an <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> signal though... Might have found something here.


<SIGNAL>PM_S0_PGOOD</SIGNAL> keeps dropping to 0v too.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Fans spin for a few seconds over and over.
threads.message: <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS</SIGNAL> must be present else there would be no fan spin or Vcore even. This could be anything at this point. Only things I can say is to inspect for corrosion again and missing/damaged parts. I doubt this "just" happened in the cupboard.
